text: {"grade": 0, "reasoning": "The criterion requires the answer to state that the right not to have a work falsely attributed (s.84 CDPA) applies to the person whose name is wrongly used. The candidate answer discusses moral rights, specifically mentioning the 'Right to be identified as author (\u201cpaternity right\u201d)' and notes that this right generally must be asserted in the UK. It does not explicitly state the legal requirement that this right applies to the person whose name is wrongly used (i.e., the author whose name *should* have been used but wasn't, or whose name was wrongly attached to someone else's work, which is the core of s.84 CDPA, the right of integrity/false attribution). While it touches upon the paternity right, it fails to confirm the specific legal scope required by the criterion regarding false attribution/misattribution.", "criterion_id": "b18b6758-1ae6-44c6-b6fe-3f5bc295de82"}
